citeinfo.origin: Jayne Belnap and Susan L. Phillips
citeinfo.title: Soil biota in an ungrazed grassland: response to annual grass (Bromus tectorum) invasion
citeinfo.othercit: Science Information System Project #: 762 Publication Control #: 1041

descript.abstract: Due to the devastating invasion of exotic plants in natural ecosystems, it is important for ecologists and land managers to understand the relationship between invasive plants and native ecosystems. In the past few years there have been many efforts directed at the aboveground, more visible impacts of invasive species on ecosystems. Unfortunately, little attention has been given to the role that the more inconspicuous soil food webs play in the invasion process and how the response of soil biota to invasive plants may influence the way native ecosystems function. Recently two USGS scientists, Jayne Belnap and Susan Phillips, published a paper discussing how the invasion of cheatgrass altered the structure of communities in Canyonlands National Park. They found that the invasion increased the quantities of some members (e.g. bacteria), while decreasing the number and richness of other members (e.g. fungi). Their findings suggest that many changes imposed upon the native ecosystem by the invading grass may be difficult or impossible to reverse. As a result they suggest that management efforts spent in preventing invasion or eliminating new invasions are likely to be more effective than trying to restore native ecosystem conditions prior to invasion.
